content: The "Arm All Pilots Act of 2015" is the short title of the Act. It facilitates and limits the training of Federal Flight Deck Officers. The Arm All Pilots Act of 2015 amends the United States Code to improve access to training facilities for Federal Flight Deck Officers by designating 5 additional firearms training facilities in various regions of the country. The Arm All Pilots Act of 2015 designates firearms training facilities for Federal flight deck officers in different regions of the United States, including facilities approved for initial training and certification of pilots seeking to be deputized. Designate additional firearms training facilities for recurrent training of Federal flight deck officers. The Secretary shall designate additional firearms training facilities for recurrent training of Federal flight deck officers, allowing requalification through training at certified gun ranges. The Secretary will determine if a Federal flight deck officer has met firearm requalification requirements by self-reporting participation in sufficient training hours. The Secretary may require initial training of up to 5 days for a pilot to become a Federal flight deck officer, with verification of training hours by the facility administrator. The Secretary may require initial training of up to 5 days for a pilot to become a Federal flight deck officer, with verification of training hours by the facility administrator. Recurrent training of not more than 2 days every 5 years may also be required to maintain deputization. The Federal flight deck officer training requirements are being amended to allow for one day of certified online training administered by the Department of Homeland Security. Additionally, pilots participating in recurrent training may be required to attend a full-day training session at the facility. The amendment includes provisions for Federal flight deck officers to take leave for training and request practice ammunition from the Secretary for monthly practice courses. SEC. 3. CARRIAGE OF FIREARMS BY FEDERAL FLIGHT DECK OFFICERS. The Secretary shall authorize Federal flight deck officers to carry firearms while engaged in providing air transportation. This includes carrying a loaded firearm on their body during duty assignments and when traveling to and from assignments. Federal flight deck officers are allowed to carry firearms while traveling, including in the passenger cabin and cockpit jump seat. They must make efforts to keep the firearm concealed in public. Officers can purchase and carry a firearm aboard an aircraft they pilot if it is approved under the program. Additionally, officers are authorized to carry firearms on international flights outside the United States. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of State, may ensure Federal flight deck officers can carry firearms in foreign countries for program participation. The Secretary must also ensure officers can carry firearms while providing foreign air transportation, aligning with policies of the federal air marshal program. The text discusses the carriage of firearms by Federal flight deck officers on flights in foreign air transportation, aligning with the policies of the Federal air marshal program. It clarifies that officers are not required to lock up their firearms when the cockpit door is opened. The Secretary of Homeland Security must issue regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment regarding the storage of firearms for Federal flight deck officers at home or while traveling. Procedural requirements under section 44921(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code, will be revised to reflect the changes made by this Act. SEC. 4. PHYSICAL STANDARDS FOR FEDERAL FLIGHT DECK OFFICERS. Section 44921(d)(2) of title 49, United States Code is amended to clarify the physical standards for Federal flight deck officers, ensuring consistency with FAA requirements. The text chunk refers to the requirements for obtaining a first- or second-class airman medical certificate from the Aviation Administration under specific regulations. SEC. 5 amends Section 44921(d) to allow Federal flight deck officers to transfer from inactive to active status after completing recurrent training. SEC. 6 facilitates security screening of Federal flight deck officers. Section 44921 of title 49, United States Code is amended to allow Federal flight deck officers expedited screening through the Known Crew Member program when entering the sterile area of an airport, without requiring paperwork. Section 44921 of title 49, United States Code is amended to allow Federal flight deck officers expedited screening through the Known Crew Member program when entering the sterile area of an airport, without requiring paperwork. Additionally, the amendment references 1540.5 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. Section 44921 of title 49, United States Code is amended to change references from "Under Secretary of Transportation for Security" to "Secretary of Homeland Security" and make adjustments to subsections (d)(4), (i)(2), and (k). Additionally, definitions for "pilot" are clarified. The final authority and responsibility for the operation and safety of the flight or any other flight deck crew member in all-cargo air transportation is now under the Secretary instead of the Under Secretary. SEC. 8 amends Section 44940 of title 49, United States Code to provide refunds of security service fees for air carriers with Federal flight deck officers on all flights. Air carriers with pilots deputized as Federal flight deck officers will receive a refund equal to 10 percent of fees collected from passengers in that fiscal year. SEC. 9 designates information about Federal flight deck officers as sensitive security information. The Secretary of Homeland Security must classify information about pilots deputized as Federal flight deck officers as sensitive security information within 180 days of this Act. Additionally, regulations necessary to implement this Act must be prescribed within the same timeframe.
